description.p: The spfe element is the root element of a SPFE configuration file.
The SPFE configuration file has five sections, which are usually separated into different files.

li.p: doc-set describes the configuration of a whole documentation set. The build scripts take a doc-set configuration as input.

object-type describes the configuration of an object type, such as graphics, used in topic sets. To include an object type configuration in your topic set configuration, use the /spfe/topic-set/object-types setting.

output-format describes the configuration of an output format, such as HTML. To include an output format configuration in your topic set configuration, use the /spfe/doc-set/output-formats/output-format setting.
topic-set describes the configuration of a topic set. To include a topic set in the doc set, use the /spfe/doc-set/topic-sets/topic-set setting.
topic-type describes the configuration of a topic type. To include an topic type configuration in your topic set configuration, use the /spfe/topic-set/topic-types/topic-type setting.

description.p: A container element for settings related to the build environment.

Specifies the build directory used to store temporary files (logs, fully resolved configuration files, scripts) generated during the build process. The default is the value of /spfe/topic-set-id appended to the value of /spfe/doc-set element appended to the value of the environment variable SPFE_BUILD_DIR.
Specifies the directory where the link catalogs will be created. The link catalogs that will be read when linking the topic set are specified by /spfe/sources/link-catalogs.
Specifies the directory where the final build output will be created.
Specifies the directory where the TOC files will be created by the topic set build. The TOCs that will be read when linking the topic set are specified by /spfe/sources/tocs.

A container element for information on a documentation set. A documentation set is a collection of topic sets. To define a documentation set, you list the configuration files for each topic set in the documentation set using a /spfe/doc-set/topic-sets/topic-set element.

To build a full documentation set, you simply run the spfe build tool with a configuration file that contains a doc-set element directly (not via inclusion). The build tool will then run whichever build command you have specified on all the topic sets in the documentation set, as well as creating the files that belong to the documentation set as a whole.
An ID for the documentation set. This value is used as the name of a directory containing the documentation set build inside the build directory.
Specifies the condition tokens that will be applied to this documentation set by the synthesis process.
An identifier for the docset.

restriction.p: The doc-set-id is used to form paths in the output, so it must be a permitted directory name on all output media.

description.p: Designates one topic set as the home topic set for the documentation set. The home topic set becomes the home for the documentation set as a whole. In many cases, a home topic set will consist of a single topic, with the name index, which will become the home page of the documentation set. However, you can include as many topics as you like in the home topic set. If you only have one topic set in your documentation set, you should designate it as the home topic set.

restriction.p: The value must match the topic set id of one topic set in the documentation set. Topic set IDs are defined in /spfe/topic-set/topic-set-id.

description.p: Specifies the types of messages that will be generated by the build. Possible value are info, and warning.
The name of the other configuration setting.
A container element for a list of output formats supported by the documentation set build.
An output format supported by the documentation set build.
The location of a file that contains the configuration file for the output format.
The name of an output format.

fragment.p: A container element for a list of string elements that define strings used by the tools or in content. This setting defines strings for . To define strings for , use .
Defines a string and gives it an ID. Strings may be used by both the build tools and in content.

The ID of the string. The string id is used to insert the string into a script or a piece of content. The markup used to insert a string may vary from one document type to another. In EPPO-Simple, the string-ref element is used.

description.p: A container element for settings related to style information used by the build tools.

A container element for a list of directories containing style files for HTML output. The specified directories will be copied into a style directory in the output directory. All subdirectories and their files will be copied as well. In the build file, it becomes an ANT resources element with the id of spfe.style.html-style-directories.

A path expression indicating style directories to be copied to the output. This path expression is used to create an include element in an ANT resources element that is used to copy style files to the output directory.
The title of the documentation set.
Defines the order in which topic set types will be listed in the doc set table of contents.
The name of a topic set type in the topic set type order list.

restriction.p: The value must match one of the values defined in /spfe/topic-set/topic-set-type for topic sets included in the doc set.

description.p: A container element for the list of topic sets in a documentation set.
The path to a topic set configuration file for a topic set to be included in the documentation set.
The URL of the configuration file for the included topic set.
The topic set id of the included topic set, it should normally match the /spfe/topic-set/topic-set-id element in the topic set's configuration file.

restriction.p: The topic-set-id is used to form file names and should be a valid file name on all target operating systems.

description.p: A container element for configuration information on the work in progress site.
A container for login information for FTP access to the work in progress site.
The ftp password for the work in progress site.
The URL of the ftp login to the work in progress site.
The user name for logging in to the work in progress site.

A container for formatting information to be passed to the formatting scripts.
A container element for settings that point to various source files used in the build.
A container element for the configuration of a topic set.
Specifies the ANT build rules file to use to build the topic set.

default.p: If this setting is not specified, the default spfe-rules.xml build rules file is used.

description.p: Specifies the condition tokens that will be applied to this topic set by the synthesis process.

Specifies the subject-affinity scope tokens to be applied to all subject-affinities in all topics in the build by default. Effectively, specifying this setting applies scope to subject-affinities that do not specify a scope. Subject affinities that declare their own scope are not affected by this setting.

Specifies the topic scope tokens to be applied to all topics in the build by default. Effectively, specifying this setting applies scope to topics that do not specify a scope. Topics that declare their own scope are not affected by this setting.
A container element for a list of object types included in a topic set.
The list of object types is used to locate the configuration file for each object type, which in turn lists the scripts used to process objects of this type.

restriction.p: Every object type occurring in the topic set must be listed here. If an unlisted object type is included, an error will occur at the synthesis stage of the build when the synthesis scripts will be unable to find templates to process the object type.

description.p: An item in the list of the object types included in a topic set. The topic type is identified by its XML namespace URI (xmlns) of the XML document that describes the individual object (for instance, a graphic record file, for a standard graphic), and the URL of its configuration file (href).

fragment.p: You can use the element to add additional configuration settings to be used by your scripts of build files.

description.p: The name of the other configuration setting.
A container element for the list of sources to be included in a topic set. Sources include authored content file, graphics, sources to extract content from, and other.

fragment.p: A container element for a list of file selectors that select the to include in the build. This becomes an ANT files expression in the build file.

description.p: Authored content includes all textual sources created by authors. It includes topics, text objects, fragments, strings (other than those defined in the configuration files), and content to be merged with extracted content.

fragment.p: A path expression indicating which to include in the build. You can use wild cards. This path expression is used to create an include element in an ANT files element that is used to copy to the build directory for inclusion in the build.

description.p: The name of the type of other source.

The topic-set-id element specifies the identifier for the current topic set. This identifier can be used to create a reference to the topic set. It is also used to create file and directory names, so it should be a value that is a valid file name (minus the extension) on all target operating systems.

fragment.p: Used in determining the link priority of a topic when there is more than one possible target for a link. The overall link priority of a topic is obtained by adding its topic set link priority to its topic type link priority, specified by .

description.p: This setting enables you to assign a type string to a topic set. You can use this element to group topic sets in output, and determine the order in which topic sets type appear in the documentation set table of contents. The order is set using the /spfe/doc-set/topic-set-type-order element. There are no special limits or requirements on this value. You can use any topic set type names that make sense in your environment. The value must match one of the values in the element /spfe/doc-set/topic-set-type-order.
A container element for a list of topic types included in a topic set.

The list of topic types is used to locate the configuration file for each topic type, which in turn lists the scripts used to process topics of this type. The list is also used to determine the topic type order for a topic set, which determines the order in which topic types are listed in a generated table of contents.

restriction.p: Every topic type occurring in the topic set must be listed here. If an unlisted topic type is included, an error will occur at the synthesis stage of the build when the synthesis scripts will be unable to find templates to process the topic type.

Note that it is possible to write a synthesis routine that attempts to process an unrecognized topic type. In this case, the error described above may not occur. This is unwise, however, since such a script cannot be guaranteed to correctly interpret all the structure of an unknown type, which may result in unanticipated effects in the output.

description.p: The location of the file that contains the configuration of a object type.

restriction.p: The setting must contain the location of a valid object type configuration file.

description.p: The XML namespace URI of the object type. This is used to unambiguously identify the ovject type.

restriction.p: This value must match the value of the targetNamespace attribute of the schema that defines the object type.

Must match the object type namespace URI declared in the object type configuration file pointed to by the href setting. In the object type configuration file, the object type namespace URI is specified in the /spfe/object-type/xmlns setting.

description.p: An item in the list of the topic types included in a topic set. The topic type is identified by its XML namespace URI (xmlns) and the URL of its configuration file (href).
The location of the file that contains the configuration of a topic type.

restriction.p: The setting must contain the location of a valid topic type configuration file.

description.p: The XML namespace URI of the topic type. This is used to unambiguously identify the topic type.

restriction.p: This value must match the value of the targetNamespace attribute of the schema that defines the topic type.

Must match the topic type namespace URI declared in the topic type configuration file pointed to by the href setting. In the topic type configuration file, the topic type namespace URI is specified in the /spfe/topic-type/xmlns setting.

The alias for the topic type id, that is, a reader-friendly name for the topic type.
The topic type id, that is, the namespace identifier of the topic type schema.

description.p: A container for the list of scripts to be used for each stage of the build process. Each build script for each stage should be written to use the standard SPFE interface for a script at that stage (which you can determine by examining the spfe.rules build rules file). Listing the full path of the script for each stage in this list will then cause that script to be called at the appropriate stage of the build process. If you need to change the interface to a script at a particular stage, you can override the build rule for that step by specifying a build rule with the same name as the one in spfe.rules. If you need to add additional steps, you can use the /spfe/topic-type/scripts/other. If you do this, you must override the normal sequence in which the scripts are run in your local build rules file (the one specified by /spfe/topic-set/build-rules).

You may specify more than one script for each stage. The build will create a temporary script file that includes each of the scripts listed for each stage. One, and only one, of the included scripts must have a template named "main", which the build rule will call as the initial template (unless you have overridden the build rule for this step in your custom build file.

This mechanism for building the final script by including a list of specified scripts allows you to customize the build for each topic set while maintaining a high degree of modularity and reuse in your script collections. A typical way to use this mechanism would be to include a separate script at the presentation stage for each of the topic types included in the build. This mechanism does not prevent you from including one script file in another in the normal way, it just gives you a more flexible way of managing modular script files and assembling the right set for each topic set.

Container element for a list of extraction scripts. The extract scripts are responsible for extracting content from external sources, which may then be combined with authored content to form complete topics.

A container for a list of formatting scripts for creating a book format of the topic set. Normally this script would produce an output in the input language of a rendering engine, such as XSL-FO or TeX. However, if you have written your own encoding script, then the formatting script should produce the input format expected by your encoding script.
A container for a list of scripts for formatting a topic set in HTML.

A container for a list of image-list scripts. Unless you have introduced custom image handling into your system, the default image handling script should work for all topic types. The image-list script is part of the format step. It generates a list of all the graphics included in the presentation so that the build scripts can copy those graphics to the appropriate location in the output.

Container element for a list of link-catalog scripts. The link-catalog step is a sub step of the presentation process. In most cases, however, the link catalog build will be run separately from the full doc build. This is to allow you to build all the link catalogs for all the topic sets in the documentation set, so that topics can link to topics in other topic sets by reading the entire collection of link catalogs to resolve subject-affinities.

A container for a named list of scripts to perform an additional step that is not part of the normal SPFE build sequence. The most usual place to user other scripts is in the synthesis step for things like extracting content from source files (the way this reference is build by extracting information from the configuration schema and combining it with authored information).
The name of the extra step.
The full path of a script that is part of the extra step.

A container for a list of presentation scripts for building a book presentation of the topic set. Usually there will be one script for the topic set as a whole and one script for each topic type in the script.

A container for a list of presentation scripts for building a web presentation of the topic set. Usually there will be one script for the topic set as a whole and one script for each topic type in the script.

Container element for a list of synthesis scripts. The synthesis scripts are responsible for assembling a set of topics in which all names are fully resolved and all conditions and inclusions have been applied.

fragment.p: The full path to script file.

description.p: A container for a list of scripts for creating a table of contents file for the topic set.
The XML schema namespace URI that identifies a topic type.
